messages: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:00): discovers that if he makes a Jabber client send namespace-ill-formed XML to a group chat, then ejabberd propagates it to all the other clients and they detect the error and disconnect
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:01): and when they reconnect and rejoin the group, the server helpfully sends the past messages to the newly-joining clients, which breaks them again
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:02): Hahahaha.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:02): Awesome.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:03): I think something is wrong. Fx fails all of the HTTP parsing tests
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:04): I'd be more concerned if it passed them all
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:06): Yes, but it doesn't even try running them.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:06): Which is why it claims to fail them all.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:06): expected_xhr.onreadystatechange is never hit :\
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:07): Interesting.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:07): Opera has changed behaviour with HTTP/0.9
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:08): Got status code 0, expected 200
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:08): Got status text , expected OK
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (20:09): chuckles at ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c and his XML games
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:09): (It works against individuals by sending normal messages too, but the server doesn't appear to resend them after the first time)
fefe4c60d912e295e59fd874577ca7f9 (20:10): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: that's pretty nasty :)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:12): Why is onreadystatechange never called?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:24): readyState is getting changed :\
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:27): https://support.process-one.net/browse/EJAB-680
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (20:27): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: would you be able to give me some statistics on the number of pages which include CRs and NULs in attribute values?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:29): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Also, could you see if you have any pages that start with "HTTP" case-insensitively but not case-sensitively?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:31): b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f: Maybe - I guess it should be easy to modify hsivonen's tokeniser to detect that
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:31): b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f: Do you care how many times per page it occurs, or just how many pages it occurs >= 1 time on?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:31): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: By "pages", do you mean the body of the page (i.e. after parsing and stripping the HTTP headers)?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:32): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: No, I mean the entire response
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:32): (i.e., what the response-line begins with)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:32): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: In that case, no
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:32): or status-line, or whatever it's called
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:32): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: since I didn't save the raw response bytes, only the parsed representation
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:33): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Ah.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:33): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: (since I couldn't see a way to make HttpClient return the raw response bytes)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:33): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Write your own! :P
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:33): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: My own HTTP client? I can't do that until someone's written a proper spec on how to write one :-p
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:34): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Oh, all I'm writing is how to parse the response/request. You don't need to do either of those :P
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:58): b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f: It looks like about 10% have \r in attribute values somewhere, and about 0% have \0
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:58): and of those 0%, most are JPEG and PDF files
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:59): Wait a minute, I'll change it to only look at text/html...
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:01): http://www.slovanova.sk/ - aha, actual HTML with a \0
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:03): waits ten minutes while it searches through all the other files
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (21:05): 10% is an interestingly high value
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:17): b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f: From something like 126989 text/html pages in total:
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:17): 16 \0 in attribute value
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:17): 10622 \r in attribute value
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:17): 47 \r\n in attribute value

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:18): (Those "\r\n" are slightly bogus - it should have aborted after finding the first "\r", but I didn't detect \rs that came after entities and got unconsumed, so it didn't notice until it got to the \n)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:20): b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f: http://philip.html5.org/data/attr-chars.txt lists them all
